bug.author: srepho
bug.summary: NaT Values in datetime columns of Dataframes get filled with a datetime value by st.write
bug.description:
<denchmark-h:h1>Summary</denchmark-h>
When creating a dataframe which contains missing datetime elements they appear with a date via st.write(). Confusingly the date is Sep 21, 1677 10:17 AM. <denchmark-h:h1>Steps to reproduce</denchmark-h>
<denchmark-code>import streamlit as st import numpy as np import pandas as pd
df= pd.DataFrame({'Date':pd.to_datetime(['2020-05-01', np.nan, '2019-08-01'])}) st.write(df) </denchmark-code>
<denchmark-h:h2>Expected behavior:</denchmark-h>
I expected that the missing date would be empty or be NaT Example from a Jupyter Lab Notebook <denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/70092369/92350639-eca78000-f11c-11ea-9e28-86f7ebe6d1f7.png></denchmark-link>
<denchmark-h:h2>Actual behavior:</denchmark-h>
<denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/70092369/92350583-c1bd2c00-f11c-11ea-8268-ee165b551dad.png></denchmark-link>
<denchmark-h:h2>Is this a regression?</denchmark-h>
Not Sure (only just started using Streamlit) <denchmark-h:h1>Debug info</denchmark-h>
Streamlit version: Streamlit, version 0.66.0 Python version: Python 3.8.5 Using Conda OS version: MacOS Catalina 10.15.6 Browser version: Chrome Version 85.0.4183.83 (Official Build) (64-bit)

comments.comment: Hey <denchmark-link:https://github.com/srepho>@srepho</denchmark-link> ! Glad you started using Streamlit. Pretty sure you hit <denchmark-link:https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/issues/594>#594</denchmark-link> unfortunately. Could you close this issue and comment on the older one to bump it up ? Cheers, Fanilo
Apologies Fanilo - I did search prior to posting but must have missed it somehow. Will comment on the older one - thanks.
No worries, Github issue search can get pretty crowded ðŸ˜‰
